Article.Abstract: Proteins encoded by DNA segment RD1 of Mycobacterium tuberculosis have recently been demonstrated to play important roles in bacterial virulence, vaccine development, and diagnostic reagent design. Previously, we characterized two immunodominant T-cell antigens, the early secreted antigen target (ESAT-6) and the 10-kDa culture filtrate protein (CFP10), which are encoded by the esx-lhp operon in this region. In the present study we characterized a third putative open reading frame in this region, rv3873, which encodes a PPE protein. We found that the rv3873 gene is expressed in M. tuberculosis H37Rv and that the native protein, Rv3873, is predominantly associated with the mycobacterial cell or wall. When tested as a His-tagged recombinant protein, Rv3873 stimulated high levels of gamma interferon secretion in peripheral blood mononuclear cells isolated from tuberculosis (TB) patients, as well as from healthy tuberculin purified protein derivative-positive donors. In contrast to other RD1-encoded antigens, Rv3873 was also found to be recognized by a significant proportion of Mycobacterium bovis BCG-vaccinated donors. Epitope mapping performed with overlapping peptides revealed a broad pattern of T-cell recognition comprising both TB-specific epitopes and epitopes also recognized by BCG-vaccinated donors. The immunodominant epitope (residues 118 to 135) for both TB patients and BCG-vaccinated individuals was found to be highly conserved among a large number of PPE family members.
Article.ArticleTitle: PPE protein (Rv3873) from DNA segment RD1 of Mycobacterium tuberculosis: strong recognition of both specific T-cell epitopes and epitopes conserved within the PPE family.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Infectious Disease Immunology, Statens Serum Institut, DK-2300 Copenhagen, Denmark. lmo@ssi.dk.
Article.ArticleChemicalList: Antigens, Bacterial;BCG Vaccine;Bacterial Proteins;CFP-10 protein, Mycobacterium tuberculosis;ESAT-6 protein, Mycobacterium tuberculosis;Epitopes, T-Lymphocyte;Peptide Fragments;Interferon-gamma
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Adult; Aged; Amino Acid Sequence; Antigens, Bacterial(immunology); BCG Vaccine(immunology); Bacterial Proteins(chemistry; immunology); Epitopes, T-Lymphocyte; Humans; Interferon-gamma(biosynthesis); Middle Aged; Molecular Sequence Data; Mycobacterium tuberculosis(chemistry; genetics; immunology); Open Reading Frames; Peptide Fragments(immunology); Tuberculosis(immunology); Vaccination

Epitope.EpitopeComments: No IFN-γ secretion is observed upon culture of PBMC from TB patients or BCG-vaccinated healthy donors with this peptide. This protein is shown to be expressed in the cell wall or cell membrane. It is encoded by an ORF located in region RD1, the first region deleted in M. Bovis during BCG vaccine propagation. Nevertheless, it is recognized by some BCG vaccinated, non-TB exposed individuals, by means of cross reactive epitopes.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMCs from tuberculosis patients were tested.
PBMCs from BCG vaccinated healthy donors were tested.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: No IFN-γ secretion is observed upon culture of PBMC from BCG-vaccinated healthy donors with this peptide. 2 out of 7 TB patients respond to this peptide. This protein is shown to be expressed in the cell wall or cell membrane. It is encoded by an ORF located in region RD1, the first region deleted in M. Bovis during BCG vaccine propagation. Nevertheless, it is recognized by some BCG vaccinated, non-TB exposed individuals, by means of cross reactive epitopes.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: IFN-γ secretion is observed upon culture with this peptide of PBMC from 1 out of 15 BCG-vaccinated healthy donors and from 4 out of 7 TB patients. A 50% sequence identity is found with a peptide from PPE family protein Rv1790 present in both M. tuberculosis and M. bovis (Table I). This protein is shown to be expressed in the cell wall or cell membrane. It is encoded by an ORF located in region RD1, the first region deleted in M. Bovis during BCG vaccine propagation. Nevertheless, it is recognized by some BCG vaccinated, non-TB exposed individuals, by means of cross reactive epitopes.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: IFN-γ secretion is observed upon culture with this peptide of PBMC from 4 out of 15 BCG-vaccinated healthy donors and from 6 out of 7 TB patients, suggesting it is immunodominant.An 89% sequence identity is found with a peptide from PPE family protein Rv3021c (aa 45-62) present in both M. tuberculosis and M. bovis (Table 1) and a similar degree of homology is found with several Mycobaterium species protein regions (Table 2). This protein is shown to be expressed in the cell wall or cell membrane. It is encoded by an ORF located in region RD1, the first region deleted in M. Bovis during BCG vaccine propagation. Nevertheless, it is recognized by some BCG vaccinated, non-TB exposed individuals, by means of cross reactive epitopes.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: PBMCs from BCG vaccinated healthy donors were tested. Similar IFN-g secretion is seen with stimulation by the source protein and with peptide. 2 donors assayed for recognition of homologous peptides present in both M. tuberculosis and M. bovis show extended cross-reactivity (Fig 4B).
